awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Challenging the broadcast allelopathy paradigm in toxigenic microbial eukaryotic ecology
awd_abstract_narration:
Harmful algal blooms in coastal marine and freshwater systems represent a serious and growing concern for human and wildlife health, particularly when these blooms of harmful algae that produce toxins. The invasive, bloom-forming alga Prymnesium parvum (aka, golden algae) has spread to more than 20 states in the last two decades, causing massive fish kills and threatening many inland recreational and commercial fisheries. While a good deal is known about the chemical nature and effects of golden algal toxins, less is understood with respect to why these toxins are produced, the mechanisms by which they are produced, or the means by which they are delivered to targeted organisms, such as fish. Researchers have long thought that golden algal toxins are produced during times of stress (as with a lack of sufficient nutrients) and released into the surrounding water to kill potential competitors and prey, thus freeing previously unavailable nutrients and alleviating the stress. In truth, however, this hypothesis is poorly supported by theoretical considerations and experimental data. This research challenges this long-standing paradigm of algal toxicity and, with the novel combination of experimentation with genetic, genomic, and analytical chemical approaches, aims to explicitly characterize how these toxins are produced and regulated, and how golden algae expose other organisms to these toxins. Expected results could transform the current toxicity paradigm and lead to significant future advances in the understanding of harmful algal blooms within the context of minimizing human and wildlife health risks associated with exposure to algal toxins.

	Broadcast allelopathy, the prevailing paradigm in protistan toxicity, lacks convincing theoretical or experimental support. The objective of this NSF-supported research is to provide clear and meaningful analysis of toxin production and delivery in the toxigenic haptophyte Prymnesium parvum. The experimental approach is twofold, involving 1) novel analytical detection of toxins during predator-prey interactions, and 2) a genome-guided genetic foundation for toxigenesis and heterotrophic nutrient acquisition. The central hypothesis is that toxigenic protists use direct cell-to-cell contact for delivery of toxins and subsequent uptake and transport of prey cell constituents across the cell membrane. The underlying rationale of this research is the recent experimental demonstration that toxicity of P. parvum is mediated by direct prey contact, as well as the theoretical consideration that delivery of exotoxins by diffusion is unlikely, and not advantageous to the fitness of individual P. parvum cells. This research is significant because it will elucidate a fundamental process through which predation and heterotrophy are supported in toxigenic protists, and will thereby potentially transform the current toxicity paradigm by definitively identifying a mechanism for toxin delivery that would provide a fitness advantage without the need for group selection arguments. Results of this study will lead to future work focused on the mechanisms of protistan cell-cell interactions, physiological and biochemical action of protistan toxins, reassessment of the role of toxicity in bloom formation, and a model for exploring other toxigenic protistan taxa and the multitude of harmful algal toxins in aquatic systems.

por.por_cntn:
The prevailing paradigm of broadcast allelopathy in pelagic microbes is poorly substantiated. The objective of this research was to provide substantive analysis of toxin production and delivery in the toxigenic haptophyte Prymnesium parvum based on novel analytical toxin detection during predator-prey interactions and a genome-guided genetic foundation for toxigenesis and heterotrophy. Due to equipment failure, we focused on the latter, supplemented with investigation into mechanistic aspects of predation.

Most researchers assume that a suite of chlorinated polyether prymnesins are the primary toxins in Prymnesium. We sought to complete a P. parvum genome in search of large polyketide synthase (PKS) gene clusters that are hypothesized as necessary for producing prymnesins. We also searched for halogenases because all previously reported prymnesins contain one to three chlorine atoms. Additionally, we conducted bioassays to compare gene expression in heterotrophic Prymnesium under balanced nutrient (N:P = 16:1) and low P (48:1) conditions that are known to affect toxicity.

We sequenced, assembled, and annotated the 134 Mb nuclear genome of P. parvum, as well as both plastid genomes. Nearly 34,000 genes were predicted, 29% of which matched functional genes in the non-redundant protein sequence database, 35% matched hypothetical genes, with the remaining 35% unmatched. Roughly 80% of the matched assignments showed phylogenetic affinity to related taxa (Chrysochromulina and Emiliania). More than 400 genes were predicted in the plastid genomes. The chloroplast genome is the largest among the published haptophyte genomes. Our annotation included 108 protein coding genes and 29 transfer RNA genes. Large rearrangements in structure of the chloroplast genome were observed when comparing with its closest relative, Emiliania huxleyi. We predicted 23 genes in the mitochondrial genome, 15 of which were annotated. The mitochondria genes were most similar to Chrysochromulina, Phaeocystis, other algae, and other taxa. Analysis of secondary metabolic biosynthesis gene clusters (smBGCs) revealed a total of 26 smBGCs, 69% of which most similar to genes in other haptophytes, such as Chrysochromulina and Emiliania. Of these, the majority were identified as non-ribosomal protein synthetases (NRPS) or NRPS-like clusters, followed by clusters encoding for terpene, heterocyst glycolipid synthase-like PKS, Type 1 and Type 3 PKS, and siderophore and aryl polyene. All smBGCs were relatively small (10-60 kb) and all but one were incomplete, suggesting that none of the identified PKS or PKS-like gene clusters were large enough for encoding prymnesins. Chemical analysis of our P. parvumsuggested the presence of several prymnesins indirectly by detection of characteristic epitopes of described toxins. However, KEGG annotation of the nuclear genome did not identify any halogenase genes, thus failing to support the production of polyether prymnesins in Prymnesium.

We quantified Prymnesium heterotrophy by measuring the change in prey (Rhodomonas salina) density after 0.5 and 4 hr of exposure to Prymnesium, as well as vacuole formation in Prymnesium using a fluorescent acidotropic probe and flow cytometry. Given the short duration of our bioassay and variability in flow-cytometric density estimates, we did not detect Prymnesium predation on Rhodomonas based on cell densities. However, the acidotropic probe assay revealed substantial heterotrophy by Prymnesium under all experimental conditions. The lack of a general nutrient effect is consistent with findings that Prymnesium was always toxic, regardless of N:P, though highest toxicities were always expressed at severe P limitation, which is corroborated by the highest observed fraction of heterotrophic Prymnesium in the presence of Rhodomonas at 0.5 hr and Low P (82.4%), with the slight drop in observed heterotrophy in the presence of Rhodomonas at 4.0 hr and Low P signaling saturation. Using RNASeq analysis, we observed differential gene expression between the two nutrient treatments. However, of the 33 genes that were significantly up- (N = 32) or down- (N = 1) regulated in the more stressful Low P treatment, only 11 were annotated. All but one were associated with mitosis regulation, secondary metabolite production, and oxidative phosphorylation. A gene coding for hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA synthase that plays a role in producing isoprenoids was significantly expressed more in Low P. This enzyme is involved in the production of isoprenoid secondary metabolites that are similar to terpene-like isoprenoids known to serve in defense against both herbivory and oxidative stress. 

In summary, multiple lines of inquiry in our research have failed to provide evidence for the production of chlorinated polyether toxins in Prymnesium. Further research will be required to definitively determine the identity of Prymnesium toxins and to advance our understanding of toxigenesis in aquatic protists within the context of minimizing human and wildlife health risks associated with exposure to protistan toxins. This project has supported six women in STEM (1 postdoc, now Research Assistant Professor; 1 Native American technician, now graduate student, 1 graduate student; and 3 undergraduate students). Information from this research will be used in harmful algal training workshops for tribal environmental monitoring personnel.
